title: 103_s1816
content: The "WIC Fraud Prosecution Act of 1994" aims to address the improper diversion of WIC benefits by stores and food vendors, imposing severe penalties on those engaged in trafficking WIC food instruments. The Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to disqualify any food vendor participating in the program for trafficking in program food instruments or engaging in unlawful activities related to program benefits. The Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to disqualify food vendors who engage in trafficking program food instruments or illegal activities related to program benefits. Vendors may face disqualification or a civil money penalty of up to $20,000 for each violation. Individuals involved in trafficking program food instruments may be fined up to $100,000 or imprisoned for up to 10 years. The Secretary may request the Attorney General to collect penalties through civil action in district court. The court has jurisdiction over the action, and the penalty amount is not subject to review. The Secretary can impose fines on individuals not approved to accept program food instruments for violations, with the fine amount determined by the Secretary. The Secretary can impose fines on individuals for violations related to program food instruments, with the amount determined by the Secretary. The Attorney General can take legal action to collect fines, with penalties increasing for subsequent convictions. The Secretary may impose fines and penalties on individuals for violations related to program food instruments, with fines ranging up to $30,000 and imprisonment for up to 5 years on subsequent convictions. Additionally, individuals convicted may face suspension from the program for up to 2 years. The Secretary also has the authority to forfeit any items or property used in trafficking violations. The Secretary can impose fines and penalties on individuals for violations related to program food instruments, with fines up to $30,000 and imprisonment for up to 5 years on subsequent convictions. Additionally, individuals convicted may face suspension from the program for up to 2 years. Forfeiture and disposal of property forfeited for violations shall be done according to regulations issued by the Secretary. SEC. 4. DETECTION OF TRAFFICKING IN WIC FOOD INSTRUMENTS OR ACCESS DEVICES. Section 17(f)(1) of the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to include a detailed plan for detecting and punishing store owners or vendors trafficking in food instruments. The plan will target higher risk stores and vendors, with funds set aside by the State agency for its implementation. The State agency must allocate funds for implementing measures to combat trafficking in food instruments and cooperate with law enforcement agencies in investigations related to the program.
